scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “As long as she was on the scene he could not take any action without a horrible exposure of the woman whom he loved.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: But the instant that she was gone he realised how crushing a misfortune this would be for you, and how all-important it was to set it right.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: He rushed down, just as he was, in his bare feet, opened the window, sprang out into the snow, and ran down the lane, where he could see a dark figure in the moonlight.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: Sir George Burnwell tried to get away, but Arthur caught him, and there was a struggle between them, your lad tugging at one side of the coronet, and his opponent at the other.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: In the scuffle, your son struck Sir George and cut him over the eye.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: Then something suddenly snapped, and your son, finding that he had the coronet in his hands, rushed back, closed the window, ascended to your room, and had just observed that the coronet had been twisted in the struggle and was endeavouring to straighten it when you appeared upon the scene.”
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “Is it possible?” gasped the banker.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “You then roused his anger by calling him names at a moment when he felt that he had deserved your warmest thanks.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: He could not explain the true state of affairs without betraying one who certainly deserved little enough consideration at his hands.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: He took the more chivalrous view, however, and preserved her secret.”
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “And that was why she shrieked and fainted when she saw the coronet,” cried Mr. Holder. “Oh, my God! what a blind fool I have been!
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: And his asking to be allowed to go out for five minutes! The dear fellow wanted to see if the missing piece were at the scene of the struggle.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: How cruelly I have misjudged him!”
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “When I arrived at the house,” continued Holmes, “I at once went very carefully round it to observe if there were any traces in the snow which might help me.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I knew that none had fallen since the evening before, and also that there had been a strong frost to preserve impressions.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I passed along the tradesmen’s path, but found it all trampled down and indistinguishable.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: Just beyond it, however, at the far side of the kitchen door, a woman had stood and talked with a man, whose round impressions on one side showed that he had a wooden leg.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I could even tell that they had been disturbed, for the woman had run back swiftly to the door, as was shown by the deep toe and light heel marks, while Wooden-leg had waited a little, and then had gone away.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I thought at the time that this might be the maid and her sweetheart, of whom you had already spoken to me, and inquiry showed it was so.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I passed round the garden without seeing anything more than random tracks, which I took to be the police; but when I got into the stable lane a very long and complex story was written in the snow in front of me.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “There was a double line of tracks of a booted man, and a second double line which I saw with delight belonged to a man with naked feet.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I was at once convinced from what you had told me that the latter was your son. The first had walked both ways, but the other had run swiftly, and as his tread was marked in places over the depression of the boot, it was obvious that he had passed after the other.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I followed them up and found they led to the hall window, where Boots had worn all the snow away while waiting.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: Then I walked to the other end, which was a hundred yards or more down the lane.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I saw where Boots had faced round, where the snow was cut up as though there had been a struggle, and, finally, where a few drops of blood had fallen, to show me that I was not mistaken.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: Boots had then run down the lane, and another little smudge of blood showed that it was he who had been hurt.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: When he came to the high road at the other end, I found that the pavement had been cleared, so there was an end to that clue.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “On entering the house, however, I examined, as you remember, the sill and framework of the hall window with my lens, and I could at once see that someone had passed out.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I could distinguish the outline of an instep where the wet foot had been placed in coming in.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I was then beginning to be able to form an opinion as to what had occurred. A man had waited outside the window; someone had brought the gems; the deed had been overseen by your son; he had pursued the thief; had struggled with him; they had each tugged at the coronet, their united strength causing injuries which neither alone could have effected.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: He had returned with the prize, but had left a fragment in the grasp of his opponent. So far I was clear.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: The question now was, who was the man, and who was it brought him the coronet?
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “It is an old maxim of mine that when you have excluded the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: Now, I knew that it was not you who had brought it down, so there only remained your niece and the maids.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: But if it were the maids, why should your son allow himself to be accused in their place? There could be no possible reason.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: As he loved his cousin, however, there was an excellent explanation why he should retain her secret—the more so as the secret was a disgraceful one.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: When I remembered that you had seen her at that window, and how she had fainted on seeing the coronet again, my conjecture became a certainty.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “And who could it be who was her confederate? A lover evidently, for who else could outweigh the love and gratitude which she must feel to
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: you? I knew that you went out little, and that your circle of friends was a very limited one.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: But among them was Sir George Burnwell. I had heard of him before as being a man of evil reputation among women.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: It must have been he who wore those boots and retained the missing gems. Even though he knew that Arthur had discovered him, he might still flatter himself that he was safe, for the lad could not say a word without compromising his own family.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “Well, your own good sense will suggest what measures I took next. I went in the shape of a loafer to Sir George’s house, managed to pick up an acquaintance with his valet, learned that his master had cut his head the night before, and, finally, at the expense of six shillings, made all sure by buying a pair of his cast-off shoes.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: With these I journeyed down to Streatham and saw that they exactly fitted the tracks.”
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “I saw an ill-dressed vagabond in the lane yesterday evening,” said Mr. Holder.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “Precisely. It was I. I found that I had my man, so I came home and changed my clothes.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: It was a delicate part which I had to play then, for I saw that a prosecution must be avoided to avert scandal, and I knew that so astute a villain would see that our hands were tied in the matter.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I went and saw him. At first, of course, he denied everything.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: But when I gave him every particular that had occurred, he tried to bluster and took down a life-preserver from the wall. I knew my man, however, and I clapped a pistol to his head before he could strike.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: Then he became a little more reasonable. I told him that we would give him a price for the stones he held—£ 1000 apiece.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: That brought out the first signs of grief that he had shown. ‘Why, dash it all!’ said he, ‘I’ve let them go at six hundred for the three!’
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: I soon managed to get the address of the receiver who had them, on promising him that there would be no prosecution. Off I set to him, and after much chaffering I got our stones at £ 1000 apiece.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: Then I looked in upon your son, told him that all was right, and eventually got to my bed about two o’clock, after what I may call a really hard day’s work.”
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “A day which has saved England from a great public scandal,” said the banker, rising. “Sir, I cannot find words to thank you, but you shall not find me ungrateful for what you have done.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: Your skill has indeed exceeded all that I have heard of it. And now I must fly to my dear boy to apologise to him for the wrong which I have done him.
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: As to what you tell me of poor Mary, it goes to my very heart. Not even your skill can inform me where she is now.”
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.

segment_text: “I think that we may safely say,” returned Holmes, “that she is wherever Sir George Burnwell is. It is equally certain, too, that whatever her sins are, they will soon receive a more than sufficient punishment.”
scene_description: bow-window, snow-covered street, Victorian room, fireplace.
